citeinfo.title: Flood Inundation Areas, La Lima, Honduras

descript.abstract: Flood inundation polygons for the 50-year flood, for Rio Chamelecon, La Lima, Honduras. Water-surface elevations for an estimated 50-year-flood discharge on Rio Chamelecon at La Lima were determined using HEC-RAS, a one-dimensional step-backwater computer program. The channel and floodplain cross section geometry used in HEC-RAS were developed from an airborne light detection and ranging (LIDAR) topographic survey of the area. The 50-year-flood discharge for Rio Chamelecon, 2400 cubic meters per second, was estimated using a regression equation that relates the 50-year-flood discharge to drainage area and mean annual precipitation. The area of inundation and depth of flood coverage was created with the HEC-RAS output and topographic TIN using HEC-geo-RAS software.
descript.purpose: The 50-year flood depth maps provide a basis for land-use planning and for engineering design of structures near or within the floodplain of the Rio Chamelecon at La Lima.

idinfo.useconst: This GIS data set has not received Director's approval and as such is provisional and subject to revision. The data are released on condition that neither the USGS nor the United States Government may be held liable for any damages resulting from its authorized or unauthorized use.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.1.1.649

citeinfo.title: Fifty-year Peak Flow Inundation Maps for La Lima, Honduras

attracc.attraccr: Based on the vertical and horizontal accuracy of the source elevation data, LIDAR.

qattracc.attracce: The estimated accuracy in meters is based on the mean elevation difference between the GPS surveys of ground-control features and the LIDAR values which was -0.125; the standard deviation of the differences was 0.092, maximum difference was 0.240 and the minimum difference was -0.350 for 1185 points at this site.

horizpa.horizpar: The horizontal accuracy is based on several sources of information: 1) The estimated 50-year flood discharge, which is based on a regression equation that uses drainage area and annual precipitation to estimate discharge is one source of error. The regression equation is based on 34 long-term stream gaging stations in Honduras and has a standard error of prediction of 71.3 percent. 2) The application of the one-dimensional hydraulic model (HEC-RAS) that is based on the assumption of gradually varied, steady flow is another source of error. The river is a natural channel with no known regulation, diversions, or split flows. Inaccuracies due to the model's limiting assumptions and solutions in only one dimesion are likely to be minimal. Errors in applying the model and estimating channel roughness by the hydrologist are difficult to assess, but they have been minimized through the USGS review process for publishing interpretive information. These sources will affect the horizontal accuracy in varying amounts at different locations and channel configurations.

qhorizpa.horizpae: The model input for channel geometry that is based on the survey made in March 2000 using airborne LIght Detection And Ranging (LIDAR) terrain mapping system may also be a source of error. Thus the horizontal accuracy is a function of the accuracy of the LIDAR or elevation and terrain model data.

qvertpa.vertacce: The estimated accuracy of the LIDAR data is based on the mean elevation difference between the GPS surveys of ground-control features and maximun, minimum, and standard deviations for 1185 points as stated in the attribute accuracy explanation.

citeinfo.title: Fifty-year Peak Flow Inundation Maps for La Lima, Honduras

procstep.procdesc: A gis file output from HEC-RAS (Hydrologic Engineering Center's River Analysis System) surface water model, is processed by the HEC-GeoRAS part of the software. This outputs an area of inundation polygon coverage. The polygons are then made into a shape file using arcshape command.
This shapefile was downloaded from an external hard drive provided by the USGS. It was then loaded into an ArcSDE 9.3.1 database via command line using the SDE command SDElayer 'create'.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in square coverage units
Length of arc in coverage units

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
